awd_titl_txt: Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy and Ultramicroelectrode Studies: Electrochemistry of Single Molecules and Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry. Professor Bard and his team at the University of Texas at Austin further develop scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) and ultramicroelectrodes to include new applications at lower concentrations (fM), and improved sensitivity. The work shifts the approach of chemical analysis for measurements of signals that arise from a very large number of molecules (ensembles) to measurements of single molecules, one at a time. Properties of single entities and effects of composition and structure can be investigated on an individual basis. The goal is to push the limits of single-entity electrochemistry to a regime of unprecedented sensitivity. The activities also contribute to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. Programs address training and technology transfer with the goal of training students and professional researchers to apply the new methods and approach to their own research problems. Young chemists participate in hands-on, multidisciplinary scientific research in areas of national importance. These researchers gain valuable experience, working closely with the PI and visiting scientists. 

In these fundamental studies, digital electrochemistry allows for single analyte species and single entities to be counted and specifically detected one at a time. The central thrust is the improved understanding of nanoparticle collision responses that is being extended to the area of detection of single atoms and potentially to single electron-transfer events. The approach is unique in focusing on: 1) understanding the detailed electrochemical responses during collision events at electrodes, 2) detecting and selectively identifying single small ions, molecules, and atoms, and 3) developing methods of detecting very small amounts of charge using nanoelectrodes (less than 10 electrons, perhaps single electron-transfer events). Young chemists are trained in advanced techniques, interact through group meetings, seminars, teaching, publishing, and conference presentations.

por.por_cntn:
Methodology developed under our previous NSF grant led to "collision electrochemistry" and especially to electrocatalytic amplification that allowed one to observe single entities, i.e. nanoparticles (NPs) or macromolecules, and even small ions. Analytical chemistry is arriving at a digital regime, where single analyte species, single entities, can be counted and specifically detected one at a time. We now have tools to detect and characterize many single entities on electrode surfaces, and analytes at femtomolar (fM) concentrations. Furthermore, properties of single entities and effects of composition and structure can be investigated on an individual basis.

     The current NSF grant continued in this endeavor by addressing the electrochemistry of single molecules and single NPs, including new applications to low concentrations (e.g., fM), improvement of sensitivity of measuring collisions. Additionally, we advanced the methodology developed in the previous NSF grant to detect and selectively identify single atoms and clusters as well as small numbers of electron transfer events, which we broadly define as digital electrochemistry. Digital electrochemistry allows for the fabrication and study of single entities, one at a time. This central thrust resulted in an improved understanding of NP collision responses, which enabled us to extend this area to the detection of single atoms and to single electron-transfer events. In this NSF grant, we pushed the limits of single-entity electrochemistry to a regime of unprecedented sensitivity by focusing on: 1) understanding the detailed electrochemical response during NP collision events, 2) detecting and selectively identifying single small ions, molecules, and atoms, and 3) developing methods of detecting very small amounts of charge (less than 10 electrons, perhaps single electron-transfer events) using nanoelectrodes. Within these studies, we demonstrated the potential to build a catalyst atom-by-atom and study its catalytic reactivity, which provided important new fundamental insights and understanding of electrocatalytic processes. 

      The intellectual merit of this NSF grant was demonstrated by changing the way in which challenges in electrochemistry are addressed.  The advancement of scientific knowledge by exploring the nature of individual interactions of single entities at electrodes revealed subtle phenomena not observable in ensemble studies. We demonstrated that stochastic electrochemistry challenges current understanding of inner-sphere heterogeneous electron transfer.  These new experiments provided new insight and a novel tool in the study of catalysis, and provided a pathway to advances in inter-conversion of chemical and electrical energy. The new experiments advanced capabilities for highly sensitive electrochemical detection, which is both transformative and aligned with commercial needs for sensors and analytical tools with higher sensitivity and selectivity, lower cost, and ease of use. Although our approach has been fundamental, and driven primarily toward the advancement of scientific knowledge, the research outcomes will transfer to industry. In fact, scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) instruments have already become commercially available from several companies, and that industry has grown from previous research in the PI's lab. 

        Broader impacts of this NSF grant were achieved in several ways.  Research activities contributed to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. Programs were in place to address training and technology transfer, with the goal of training students and professional researchers to apply the new methods and approaches to their own research problems. Excellent opportunities were provided for the training of young chemists, who participated in hands-on, multidisciplinary scientific research in areas of national importance. The PI's laboratory is recognized internationally as a unique center of excellence, with a highly productive and interactive group fostering broad exchange in the field of electrochemistry. These researchers gained valuable experience, working closely with the PI and visiting scientists. They were trained in advanced techniques, interacting through group meetings, departmental seminars, undergraduate teaching, scientific publishing, and conference presentations.
